_header: Whilom there was an high and mighty prince
Note:
See 5116; facs. X
Lyf of St. Ursula [facsimiles from de Worde 1509, STC 24541.3 and STC 17014.7]
Roxburghe Club 24. London: From the Shakespeare Press, by W. Bulmer and Co., 1818.
_description: Gilbert Banester, The Tale of Guiscardo and Ghismonda (Version A) — in rhyme royal

BodRawC86.First Lines:
…Eche to othir þay suffir most payneThe wykked daunger
                    and envyous Ielosye…
BodRawC86.Last Lines:
…Is lord and gouernour comfort ayenst baleGraunt þes
                    lovers Ioy so endith my tale
BodRawC86.Note:
610 lines in rhyme royal, except 17-line prologue in couplets; plus
                    fragmentary prologue of 17 lines (f. 143; tale itself, ‘Whylome was
                    þer an hygh & myghty prynce…’, begins f. 143v)
                    and missing envoy; possibly text on f. 142v part of prologue, since
                    title appears there: see 4096.
BodRawC86.Editions:
Wright,  Herbert Gladstone,
                        ed.  
             Early English Versions of the Tales of Guiscardo and Ghismonda and
                Titus and Gisippus from the Decameron.
EETS
         o.s. 205 (1937); repr. 1988: 2-38.

BLAdd12524.First Lines:
Whilom ther was ane hyght & myghty princeIn Salern tawker
                    þei clepyd hys name…
BLAdd12524.Last Lines:
…Speke to Gilbert banester which at the mociouneOff Iohn
                    Raynere this made aftir þe sentence
BLAdd12524.Note:
625 lines, with Envoy; a nineteenth-century transcript by John Holmes is
                        London,  British Library Addit. 20775.
BLAdd12524.Editions:
Wright,  Herbert Gladstone,
                        ed.  
             Early English Versions of the Tales of Guiscardo and Ghismonda and
                Titus and Gisippus from the Decameron.
EETS
         o.s. 205 (1937); repr. 1988: 2-38.
